items.summary: Get or set the children elements.
items.name: wibox.widget.base.children

items.summary: Get all direct and indirect children widgets.
items.name: wibox.widget.base.all_children
items.description:
This will scan all containers recursively to find widgets
 Warning: This method it prone to stack overflow if there is a loop in the
 widgets hierarchy. A hierarchy loop is when a widget, or any of its
 children, contain (directly or indirectly) itself.

items.description: The table contains a list of `awful.button` objects.
items.summary: The widget buttons.
items.name: wibox.widget.base.buttons

items.description:
This signal is emitted when the previous results of `:layout()` and `:fit()`
 are no longer valid.  Unless this signal is emitted, `:layout()` and `:fit()`
 must return the same result when called with the same arguments.
items.summary: When the layout (size) change.
items.name: widget::layout_changed

items.description:
This signal is emitted when the content of the widget changes. The widget will
 be redrawn, it is not re-layouted. Put differently, it is assumed that
 `:layout()` and `:fit()` would still return the same results as before.
items.summary: When the widget content changed.
items.name: widget::redraw_needed

map.o:
The opacity to use (a number from 0 (transparent) to 1
 (opaque)).

items.summary: Set a widget's opacity.
items.name: wibox.widget.base:set_opacity

items.summary: Get the widget's opacity.
items.name: wibox.widget.base:get_opacity

map.width:
With `nil` the default mechanism of calling the
   `:fit` method is used.

items.summary: Set the widget's forced width.
items.name: wibox.widget.base:set_forced_width

items.description:
Note that widget instances can be used in different places simultaneously,
 and therefore can have multiple dimensions.
 If there is no forced width/height, then the only way to get the widget's
 actual size is during a `mouse::enter`, `mouse::leave` or button event.
items.summary: Get the widget's forced width.
items.name: wibox.widget.base:get_forced_width

map.height:
With `nil` the default mechanism of calling the
   `:fit` method is used.

items.summary: Set the widget's forced height.
items.name: wibox.widget.base:set_height

items.summary: Get the widget's forced height.
items.name: wibox.widget.base:get_forced_height
items.description:
Note that widget instances can be used in different places simultaneously,
 and therefore can have multiple dimensions.
 If there is no forced width/height, then the only way to get the widget's
 actual size is during a `mouse::enter`, `mouse::leave` or button event.

items.summary: Get the widget's direct children widgets.
items.name: wibox.widget.base:get_children
items.description: This method should be re-implemented by the relevant widgets.

map.children: A table composed of valid widgets.

items.summary: Replace the layout children.
items.name: wibox.widget.base:set_children
items.description:
The default implementation does nothing, this must be re-implemented by
 all layout and container widgets.

items.summary: Get all direct and indirect children widgets.
items.name: wibox.widget.base:get_all_children
items.description:
This will scan all containers recursively to find widgets.

 *Warning*: This method it prone to stack overflow if the widget, or any of
 its children, contains (directly or indirectly) itself.
Use this if your widget has no custom logic when setting the widget.
items.summary:
Common implementation of the `:set_widget()` method exposed by many
 other widgets.
items.name: wibox.widget.base:set_widget_common

items.summary:
Emit a signal and ensure all parent widgets in the hierarchies also
 forward the signal.
items.name: wibox.widget.base:emit_signal_recursive
items.description:
This is useful to track signals when there is a dynamic set of containers
   and layouts wrapping the widget.

 Note that this function has some flaws:

 1. The signal is only forwarded once the widget tree has been built. This
    happens after all currently scheduled functions have been executed.
    Therefore, it will not start to work right away.
 2. In case the widget is present multiple times in a single widget tree,
    this function will also forward the signal multiple times (once per upward
    tree path).
 3. If the widget is removed from the widget tree, the signal is still
    forwarded for some time, similar to the first case.

Additional widgets to add at the end of the
   sub-widgets hierarchy "path".
map.recursive:
Recursively check accross the sub-widgets
   hierarchy.

items.summary: Get the index of a widget.
items.name: wibox.widget.base:index

items.summary: Figure out the geometry in the device coordinate space.
items.name: wibox.widget.base.rect_to_device_geometry
items.description:
This gives only tight bounds if no rotations by non-multiples of 90Â° are
 used.

map.parent: The parent widget which requests this information.
map.context: The context in which we are fit.
map.widget:
The widget to fit (this uses
   `widget:fit(context, width, height)`).
map.height: The available height for the widget.
map.width: The available width for the widget.

items.summary: Fit a widget for the given available width and height.
items.name: wibox.widget.base.fit_widget
items.description:
This calls the widget's `:fit` callback and caches the result for later use.
 Never call `:fit` directly, but always through this function!

map.parent: The parent widget which requests this information.
map.context: The context in which we are laid out.
map.widget:
The widget to layout (this uses
   `widget:layout(context, width, height)`).
map.height: The available height for the widget.
map.width: The available width for the widget.

items.summary: Lay out a widget for the given available width and height.
items.name: wibox.widget.base.layout_widget
items.description:
This calls the widget's `:layout` callback and caches the result for later
 use.  Never call `:layout` directly, but always through this function!
 However, normally there shouldn't be any reason why you need to use this
 function.

items.summary: Handle a button event on a widget.
items.name: wibox.widget.base.handle_button
items.description: This is used internally and should not be called directly.

map.width:
The width of the widget in its own coordinate system.
   That is, after applying the transformation matrix.
map.widget: The widget that should be placed.
map.height:
The height of the widget in its own coordinate system.
   That is, after applying the transformation matrix.
map.mat:
A matrix transforming from the parent widget's coordinate
   system. For example, use matrix.create_translate(1, 2) to draw a
   widget at position (1, 2) relative to the parent widget.

items.summary: Create widget placement information.
items.name: wibox.widget.base.place_widget_via_matrix
items.description:
This should be used in a widget's
 `:layout()` callback.

map.x: The x coordinate for the widget.
map.y: The y coordinate for the widget.
map.widget: The widget that should be placed.
map.height:
The height of the widget in its own coordinate system.
   That is, after applying the transformation matrix.
map.width:
The width of the widget in its own coordinate system.
   That is, after applying the transformation matrix.

items.summary: Create widget placement information.
items.name: wibox.widget.base.place_widget_at
items.description:
This should be used for a widget's
 `:layout()` callback.

map.args: A table containing the widget's disposition.

items.summary: Set a declarative widget hierarchy description.
items.name: wibox.widget.base:setup
items.description: See [The declarative layout system](../documentation/03-declarative-layout.md.html).

map.args: A table containing the widgets disposition.

items.summary: Create a widget from a declarative description.
items.name: wibox.widget.base.make_widget_declarative
items.description: See [The declarative layout system](../documentation/03-declarative-layout.md.html).

Arguments passed to the contructor (if any).

items.summary: Create a widget from an undetermined value.
items.name: wibox.widget.base.make_widget_from_value
items.description:
The value can be:

 * A widget (in which case nothing new is created)
 * A declarative construct
 * A constructor function
 * A metaobject

map.proxy:
If this is set, the returned widget will be a
   proxy for this widget. It will be equivalent to this widget.
   This means it looks the same on the screen.
map.args.enable_properties:
Enable automatic getter
   and setter methods.
map.widget_name:
Name of the widget.  If not set, it will be
   set automatically via @{gears.object.modulename}.

items.description: See [Creating new widgets](../documentation/04-new-widgets.md.html).
items.summary: Create an empty widget skeleton.
items.name: wibox.widget.base.make_widget

items.summary: Generate an empty widget which takes no space and displays nothing.
items.name: wibox.widget.base.empty_widget

items.summary: Do some sanity checking on a widget.
items.name: wibox.widget.base.check_widget
items.description: This function raises an error if the widget is not valid.
